Award.AwardTitle: Addressing the precision-plasticity paradox in metazoan gene regulatory networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to discover how intracellular and environmental signals change the repertoire of genes activated by DNA-binding proteins. In a particular cellular, developmental and physiological context, DNA-binding proteins normally operate with precision to control a specific network of target genes. However, changes in cellular or extracellular conditions can increase the plasticity of protein-DNA interactions, such that an entirely different group of genes is targeted. This kind of switch from precision to plasticity may hold the key to proper development in multicellular organism, like humans, and dissecting the underlying mechanisms may improve our understanding of how organisms maintain their well-being in the face of environmental fluctuation. In addition to the expected scientific achievements, tackling this research problem will strengthen and enrich the scientific enterprise by providing training and educational opportunities for two women scientists and for a cohort of undergraduate students, including those who are underrepresented minorities. Classic and state-of-art genetic and molecular approaches used in this project will serve as exciting stimuli for the education of budding scientists, as well as a conceptual framework for reasoning and problem solving for the education of those who choose other career paths.

The long-term goal of this research is to understand the molecular mechanisms that generate the remarkable specificity with which gene transcription is regulated in multicellular eukaryotes. Based on prior work in this laboratory, a bipartite model has emerged whereby a given DNA-binding transcriptional regulatory factor (TF) can either operate precisely to regulate a specific set of gene targets or, under conditions that promote plasticity, operate to regulate an entirely different set of genes. The model contends that intra- or extracellular signals create a specific context that governs how the TF will associate with other DNA-binding and non-DNA-binding coregulatory factors to activate distinct networks of gene targets. This model will be tested in the nematode, Caenorhabditis elegans, which offers unique features including a compact genome, facile spatiotemporal analyses in the intact organism, powerful genetics, and a comprehensive suite of genomics tools, including CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing. The research will focus on the precise vs. plastic action of the nuclear hormone receptor TF, NHR-25. Previous results showed that a gradient of NHR-25 activity--set up by differential post-translational sumoylation (SUMO) of the protein--in neighboring cells drives distinct gene networks that result in unique cell fates and subsequent tissue differentiation and organogenesis. The complexity of transcription network control will be addressed experimentally to: define and analyze cell-context dependent NHR-25-SUMO regulatory networks; identify pathways and machineries that enable NHR-25 regulatory plasticity; and prepare materials for enChIP analysis to identify proteins associating at NHR-25 dependent response elements. The results obtained will be broadly relevant to metazoan transcriptional regulation and provide an important foundation for future studies of gene regulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regulated expression of genes is a universal and essential biological process that is controlled by cellular proteins called transcriptional regulatory factors (TFs). TFs interpret environmental and developmental signals that work in combination to provoke cells to express unique patterns of genes in different settings, or contexts. We sought in this project to understand how a particular TF controls precisely defined gene networks in a given context, yet efficiently displays plasticity, altering the regulated network when the context is altered. We used forward and reverse genetics, powerful experimental tools, to discover genes and signaling pathways essential for the TF's regulatory precision and plasticity in specific cells and in C. elegans, a simple round worm, which displays numerous advantages for designing and interpreting scientific experiments. 

NHR-25 is a C. elegans TF from the nuclear receptor NR5A superfamily, which is conserved across multicellular animals, including humans. NHR-25 regulates numerous gene networks that govern multiple aspects of development (e.g. cell fate decisions, organogenesis) and homeostasis (e.g. lipid metabolism, stress response). Some of NHR-25's capacity to regulate particular genes stems from its recognition of specific DNA elements positioned close to candidate target genes. In prior work, we had identified those sequences, denoted as NR5 response elements or NR5REs. We fused multiple copies of the element close to a fluorescent gene (8xNR5RE::Venus) to visualize the activity of NHR-25 in the cells of live animals. In a forward genetic screen, we chemically mutated the genome and found two genes essential for NHR-25 function. UBA-2 is a gene product necessary for sumoylation, a signaling process that alters the structure, and thereby the activity, of NHR-25. Other genes that mediate the sumoylation process were further tested by a reverse genetics approach, RNAi, and confirmed that all genes involved in sumoylation of NHR-25 were required for proper regulation of NHR-25 target gene expression. 

We discovered that lir-2 is a TF "co-regulator" that confers regulatory activity on NHR-25 by interacting with it through "LxxLL" amino acid sequence motifs on LIR-2; this motif is known to be typical for nuclear receptor co-regulators. We demonstrated the interaction biochemically, and used reverse genetics, creating a series of lir-2 mutants by CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing, to show genetically that proper target gene regulation by NHR-25 required the LIR-2 LxxLL motifs. Our finding is the first functional determination for the lir-2 gene. 

The expression profile of the 8xNR5RE::Venus reporter gene was similar but not identical in sumo-defective individuals and lir-2 mutants, where expression in particular epidermal cells called seam cells was strikingly different. This indicates that sumoylation and LIR-2 coregulation affect NHR-25 regulatory activity through different mechanisms to execute cell-specific gene expression. Identification of distinct context-specific transcriptional regulatory complexes at particular NR5REs will be the next step to define and understand transcription network control.

To begin to define NHR-25 regulated gene networks in C. elegans,we used a method termed ChIP-seq to map positions of specific NHR-25 genome binding at early larval stages when NHR-25 is highly active. We used CRISPR-Cas9 mutagenesis to alter the NR5RE binding sequences and surrounding DNA at six NHR-25 binding regions. We found by RNA-seq that genes close to the mutant regions were selectively misregulated, although interestingly, it was not always the gene closest to the mutation that was affected. Notably, over 80% of the NHR-25 binding regions contained a binding motif for EOR-1, a zinc finger protein involved in a recruitment of factors to target genes, perhaps indicating that EOR-1 opens chromatin accessibility to NHR-25. For these studies, we have adapted for C. elegans a DNA-protein profiling method, CUT&RUN, which requires less material and provides a stronger signal:noise ratio than ChIP-seq.

In addition to studies executed at UCSF, this grant provided support for Dr. Deborah Thurtle-Schmidt to establish a position as an independent investigator at an excellent undergraduate institution, Davidson College in Davidson, NC. REU supplemental funding was secured to support her undergraduate student, Alex Sinks. That support resulted in Dr. Thurtle-Schmidt being offered, and accepting, a tenure-track assistant professor position at Davidson. This grant also provided the opportunity for Dr. Masako Asahina, who transited from Eastern Europe, to continue her research career and expand her skills at a leading US institution, establishing a base for her outstanding studies.
